thread.title: Two Die at Indian Bull-Taming Event, Protesters Clash With Police - India Real Time - WSJ
thread.title_full: Two Die at Indian Bull-Taming Event, Protesters Clash With Police - India Real Time - WSJ

author: Karan Deep Singh
title: Two Die at Indian Bull-Taming Event, Protesters Clash With Police - India Real Time - WSJ
text:
Fans of the Indian sport of bull taming clashed with police in Chennai, capital of the southern state of Tamil Nadu Monday , a day after two men were killed by a bull at an event in the state. ENLARGE Police remove a demonstrator from Marina beach during a protest in Chennai, India, January 23, 2017. Photo: Reuters More In jallikattu ‘Barbaric’ Bull-Baiting Banned in India 
India’s government on Saturday temporarily allowed the sport, known as Jallikattu, which was banned in 2014 by the country’s highest court over animal-cruelty concerns. 
Two men died Sunday after being gored by a bull at an event in Rapoosal in Pudukkottai district, police said. ENLARGE A participant hangs on to the horn of a bull during a Jallikattu event in Palamedu, about 434 kilometers (269 miles) south of Chennai. Photo: Arun Sankar K./Associated Press 
Protesters started gathering in Chennai last week to demand they be allowed to hold Jallikattu events during Pongal , the annual harvest festival which takes place in January. ENLARGE Indian students held up placards during a demonstration against the ban on the Jallikattu bull taming ritual, and calling for a ban on animal rights orgnisation PETA, Marina Beach, Chennai, Jan. 18 2017. Photo: Agence France-Presse/Getty Images 
A section of India’s animal cruelty law prohibits bulls from being used as “performing animals.” 
Animal-rights activists say the sport is cruel because the animals can get hurt. Fans of the sport have asked courts to allow Jallikattu to take place, saying it holds cultural significance. ENLARGE A bull charged through a crowd of Indian participants and bystanders during Jallikattu, an annual bull fighting ritual, on the outskirts of Madurai, Jan. 15, 2017. Photo: Arun Sankar/Agence France-Presse/Getty Images 
On Monday police in Chennai tried to evict protesters from the Marina Beach area, where thousands have gathered over the past week. Protesters threw stones and set fire to vehicles as police tried to drag them away. ENLARGE Protestors hold placards demanding Jallikattu be allowed to resume as thousands gather at the Marina beach in Chennai, India, Sunday, Jan.22, 2017. Photo: Associated Press 
P. Dhanapal, speaker of the state assembly, said Monday that a special legislative session will be held to pass an amendment to the law, allowing the sport to be played in the state.
